H0.text: The air heating the sidewalk is probably causing the ice on the sidewalk to melt, even though a thermometer shows the outside air temperature is colder than the temperature at which water turns to ice.

H1.text: The sidewalk reflecting sunlight into the air is what probably caused the ice on the sidewalk to melt even though the thermometer shows that the outside air temperature is colder than the temperature at which water turns to ice.

H2.text: The wind causing the ice on the sidewalk to melt is probably responsible for the ice melting even though the thermometer shows the outside air temperature is colder than the temperature at which water turns to ice.

H3.text: The sunlight making the sidewalk warmer than the air probably caused the ice on the sidewalk to melt, even though the thermometer shows that the outside air temperature is colder than the temperature at which water turns to ice.

A4.text: The warming of the ground (and other objects) depends on the absorption of the electromagnetic radiation in the form of heat.

A5.text: When direct solar radiation is not blocked by clouds, it is experienced as sunshine, a combination of bright light and radiant heat.
